• RIGHT: (8,7) is occupied by part of the enemy snake’s body.
• DOWN: (7,6) is part of our own body.
• LEFT: (6,7) appears clear (the board shows a “.” there).

With only one safe cell, our only viable move is to go LEFT.

I’ll choose LEFT as the next move.

1.rationale:
Let's analyze our current situation step‐by‐step.

Our board (using 0–9 for x and y) shows our snake’s head as the single digit “1” at (6,7). Our body cells occupy:
  • (7,7)
  • (7,6)
  • (7,5)
  • (6,5)
  • (5,5)
  • (5,6)
  • (4,6)
  • (4,7)
  • (3,7)
  • (2,7)
  • (1,7)

The enemy snake (#0) has its head “0” at (6,8) with its body trailing in the nearby cells.

Looking at our immediate options from our head at (6,7):

• UP would send us to (6,8). That cell is occupied by the enemy snake’s head – not safe.
• RIGHT would send us to (7,7) – but that’s already part of our own body.
• DOWN from (6,7) would be (6,6). However, even though (6,6) appears empty on the board, if we simulate the move our snake’s body shifts. After moving down:
  – New head becomes (6,6)
  – Our old head (6,7) becomes part of our body
  – The rest of our body shifts and the tail (1,7) is removed.
  Checking the neighbors of the new head at (6,6):
   ▪ UP: (6,7) becomes our new S1.
   ▪ RIGHT: (7,6) is still in our body.
   ▪ LEFT: (5,6) remains in our body.
   ▪ DOWN: (6,5) remains blocked by our body.
  Thus, moving DOWN would trap us immediately.
• LEFT would send us to (5,7). If we simulate that:
  – New head: (5,7)
  – Our old head (6,7) becomes our first body segment, and the tail (1,7) is removed.
  Then from (5,7) the adjacent cells are:
   ▪ UP: (5,8) – which is free.
   ▪ RIGHT: (6,7) – our new body segment.
   ▪ DOWN: (5,6) – still part of our body.
   ▪ LEFT: (4,7) – in our body.
  So at least one exit (UP from (5,7)) is available for our next move.

None of the immediate moves score an apple, but safety is top priority. The apple positions we see (at (5,1), (1,3), (6,4), (3,6), and (3,4)) remain accessible later. For now, our goal is to keep alive and to avoid collisions. The analysis shows that of our four potential directions, only moving LEFT is safe immediately.

Therefore, my decided next move is: LEFT.

0.rationale:
Thinking through the options from head at (6,8):

  • DOWN to (6,7) is occupied by the enemy.  
  • LEFT to (5,8) would then be boxed in (down is also enemy).  
  • RIGHT to (7,8) is my own body.  
  • UP to (6,9) is the only free spot.  

Although moving up puts me against the wall, it’s the only non-fatal choice and starts opening a route around the block of snakes to head for the apple cluster on the left.

Next move: UP

1.rationale:
Let’s walk through our reasoning:

• Our snake’s head is at (6,7) and our body extends from there. (Note: the board symbols show “1” a bit to the left, but our simulated head is at (6,7) as used in our reasoning.) 
• If we try to go UP from (6,7), we move into (6,8) where the enemy snake’s head sits—collision. 
• Going RIGHT would take us into (7,7), which is part of our own body—collision. 
• Going DOWN would land us at (6,6). But after that move our options are blocked by our body: UP would reverse into our new body cell, RIGHT and LEFT are still occupied, and DOWN is blocked too. That path leads to a dead-end. 
• Moving LEFT sends us to (5,7). Simulating this move, our head becomes (5,7) and our body shifts (with the tail cell disappearing). From the new head’s neighbors:
  – UP (5,8) is free,
  – RIGHT (6,7) is now a body part but won’t be there in time,
  – DOWN (5,6) and LEFT (4,7) are still occupied, but at least we have an escape route by going UP on the following turn.

There are apples elsewhere on the board, but for now our top priority is to remain safe. With LEFT being the only move that doesn’t result in immediate collision or trap us, that is our best bet for avoiding danger.

Therefore, my decided next move is: LEFT.
